div1.p: Special Orders #32 details Springer to the Army Medical Museum in Washington, D. C. and Colby to Camp Mackenzie, Cuba. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Adolph F. Springer and Newell R. Colby, February 7, 1901
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, February 7, 1901.

1. In compliance with paragraph 18, Special Orders No.
26, current series, Headquarters of the Army, Private
Adolph F. Springer, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, is hereby
relieved from duty at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and will
proceed to Washington, D. C., reporting upon arrival to
Major John Van R. Hoff, Surgeon, U. S. Army, medical
supply officer, for duty in the pathological laboratory of the
Army Medical Museum.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department will
commute his rations, in advance, at the authorized rate, for
one (1) day while delayed in New York City and traveling
by rail.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. The following named enlisted men of the Hospital
Corps, U. S. Army, are hereby relieved from duty at Co-
lumbia Barracks, Cuba, and will proceed to the places set
opposite their respective names and report to the command-
ing officer for duty:

Acting Hospital Steward Newell R. Colby, Camp Mac-
kenzie, Puerto Príncipe, Cuba;

Private John W. Rutledge, Santa Clara Battery, Havana,
Cuba.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

J. B. HICKEY,
Acting Adjutant General.
